awd_titl_txt: Physical Properties of the Coolest Brown Dwarfs
awd_abstract_narration:
Brown dwarfs are key laboratories for understanding the differences between the smallest stars and the largest extrasolar planets.  This program will expand our understanding of the coldest known brown dwarfs through a major observational program to determine their physical properties down to about 5 times the mass of Jupiter.  Undergraduate and graduate students will develop expertise in two key areas of ground-based astronomy, namely wide-field astrometry and laser guide star adaptive optics.  In parallel, the PI will formalize and enhance a professional development initiative to teach graduate students the soft skills needed for long-term success.  This effort is geared towards enhancing students as budding researchers, helping them navigate the complexities of academia, and increasing retention along the career pipeline.

This observational program will use high-precision infrared astrometry to measure distances, and thus absolute magnitudes and luminosities, for a well-defined sample of the coolest brown dwarfs.  High angular resolution adaptive optics imaging will establish the multiplicity properties of these objects and yield the coolest known binaries. Follow-up characterization of the binaries will result in resolved spectrophotometry and dynamical masses, enabling the strongest tests to date of substellar evolutionary models and ultracool atmospheres.

por.por_cntn:
Brown dwarfs are key laboratories for understanding the continuum ofphysics that binds together low-mass stars and gas-giant extrasolarplanets. Our program studied the coldest known brown dwarfs (down to ~5Jupiter masses) using high--resolution infrared imaging and spectroscopyfrom the Keck laser guide star adaptive optics (LGS AO) system. Ourprogram had two components:


(1) We measured direct distances for a well-defined populous sample ofthe coolest brown dwarfs, based on a continuation of the Hawaii InfraredParallax Program at the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope. Direct distancemeasurements of these objects allow us to determine their total energyoutput (a.k.a. the luminosity), which are to understanding the evolutionand atmospheres of such low-temperature objects. Parallaxes provide theonly direct, model-independent method for determining such distances.Combined with existing photometry and spectroscopy, our data preciselydetermined the energy output, establishing a rich empirical census fortracing substellar evolution, testing current theoretical models, andproviding context for directly imaged extrasolar planets (whose massesand temprerature overlap that of the coolest brown dwarfs).


(2) We conducted a deep, sensitive imaging survey of the coldest knownbrown dwarfs using Keck laser guide star adaptive optics (LGS AO) toidentify new binary systems suitable for dynamical mass determinations.Kepler's Third Law tells us that measuring the combination of theorbital period of such binaries and their orbital separation gives thetotal mass of the binary, a quantity which is otherwise impossible tomeasure. In addition, deep Keck LGS AO imaging allows us to find evencooler temperature objects as companions to known objects. Thestatistics of binarity, such as the binary frequency and the mass ratiosof the binary components, are key observational constraints on theoriesof brown dwarf formation.
